title: Events: Cherubs and Tigers in Trees

body: Decorative Pursuits Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (66th Street); (212) 472-1180. "Modernism: A Century of Style and Design," a show and sale featuring furniture, jewelry, decorative objects, textiles, prints, lamps and clocks in styles including Arts and Crafts, Prairie School, Art Moderne, Art Deco, Bauhaus and Gothic Revival, runs
title: Events: Good Design, Indoors or Out

body: Arts and Crafts American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535. The museum will offer a number of talks in conjunction with "The Ideal Home: 1900-1920," an exhibition about the Arts and Crafts movement that will continue through Feb. 27. The role of women in the movement will be explored in a three-lecture series starting Tuesday with
title: Calendar: Crafts, Antiques and Roses

body: Bonsai Bounty Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433. The Tri-State and Mid-Atlantic Bonsai Societies are sponsors of a show of more than 60 indoor and outdoor bonsai plants that starts Saturday and continues through Oct. 31. A plant sale will be held from noon to 4 P.M. each day. On
title: Calendar: Bonsai And the Falling Leaves

body: Chili and Gardening Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433. title: Events: Gardening And Crafts

body: AUNT SONIA (Article) (718) 965-9526; 1123 Eighth Avenue, at 12th Street, Park Slope; $$; AE, MC, V This down-home, casual place, named for the nearby Ansonia Clock Building, serves engaging fare at bargain prices. The chef, Michael Schrieber, is a self-taught cook who, with his partner, Wayne Perez, turned a former bric-a-brac shop into a pleasant
title: GOOD EATING; A World of Food, River to Slope

body: Architect's Exhibition Architectural League of New York, the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 980-3767. An exhibition of drawings, photographs and models of residences and commercial buildings designed since 1980 by Franklin D. Israel starts Monday and continues through Oct. 27. Mr. Israel will give a talk on Sept. 23 at 7 P.M.
title: Events: Art, Talks

body: Talking About Cities Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960. On Tuesday at 6 P.M., there will be an illustrated lecture on efforts by communities to develop their waterfront areas. Admission is $5; members, $3. Reservations are required. A series of six lectures by architectural and urban writers begins Sept. 16,
title: Calendar: Talks and Harvest Fairs

body: Grueby Show Craftsman Farms, 2352 Route 10 West (two and a half miles west of Interstate 287), Parsippany, N.J.; (201) 540-1165. An exhibition of Grueby pottery from the Arts and Crafts Movement will be held from noon to 7:30 P.M. Saturday and from 11 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Sunday. Grueby was known for its freehand floral designs and the quality of its
title: Events: Grueby Pottery

body: Art Tours Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street at Central Avenue, Newark; (201) 596-6550. There will be a day trip to two collections in Long Island City next Wednesday: the Noguchi Garden Museum and the Fisher-Landau Center, which features works by Georgia O'Keeffe, Jean Dubuffet, Piet Mondrian and Pablo Picasso. Fee is $61. On Sept. 18, there will
title: Events: Art Tours, Crafts, Gardens

body: Four Days of Crafts Lincoln Center, Columbus Avenue at 64th Street; (212) 677-4627. The American Crafts Festival will be held Saturday and Sunday and again on July 10 and 11, with more than 400 artists displaying their crafts, plus entertainment and food stalls. The second weekend will feature demonstrations of glass etching, knitting and
title: Events: Crafts, Gardens, Park Walks

body: With a belated package of Federal financing about to be approved by Congress, government agencies and community groups in New York City are gearing up for a summer jobs program for teen-agers that promises fewer jobs and shorter periods of employment than in recent years. The Federal program, a cornerstone of the nation's efforts to give poor young
title: Cutback in U.S. Funds to Reduce Summer Jobs for New York Youths

body: Four men were convicted of attempted murder in Brooklyn yesterday in the attack on a Greek Orthodox Bishop last year, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn said. The four men, aged 18 to 20, each pleaded guilty to trying to kill Bishop Alexios Panagiotopoulos during an attempted robbery outside his home in Crown Heights on Feb. 26, 1992,
title: 4 Convicted of Attempted Murder of Bishop

body: Bronx voters returned to office the former presidents of two corruption-plagued community school boards who were removed from office recently amid accusations of wrongdoing, according to results of the May 4 school board election released yesterday. The voters in Districts 9 and 12 in the Bronx also re-elected several other present and former board
title: Ousted Chiefs Due to Rejoin School Boards

body: Wright Community Municipal Art Society, the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 397-3809. A series of tours continues on Saturday from 1 to 6 P.M. with a bus trip to Usonia, a Westchester community designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in the 1950's. A $60 fee includes a $10 donation to the Frank Lloyd Wright Building Conservancy; for
title: Events: Tours and Fairs, Quilts and Azaleas

body: Teapot Territory American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street; (212) 956-3535. An exhibition and benefit sale of teapots and tea accessories by more than 150 artists will be held from Tuesday through May 2. Tea will be served each day from 3 to 5 P.M. Hours: Tuesday through Sunday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. (until 8 P.M. on Tuesdays). Admission is $4.50; for
title: Events: Teapot Show And Cherry Blossoms

body: Focus on Vegetables Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433. "Making Brooklyn Bloom," a program on Sunday from 12:30 to 4 P.M. that is sponsored by the garden and by Cornell Cooperative Extension, will feature a guided behind-the-scenes tour of the greenhouses from 1 to 2 P.M and,
title: Calendar: Blooms, Photos And Tours

body: A PROFESSIONAL bass player named Yasutomo Takeda has yet to meet a professional sax player named Jeff Lederer. But once they meet they will find they have more in common than their careers. And meet they will. They and their wives have gone into contract to buy condominium apartments in the newly renovated four-story walk-up at 1405 Eighth Avenue
title: Perspectives: Park Slope Condominiums; Finding the Iron Hot, Young Buyers Strike

body: Three people were shot, two of them fatally, in an apartment in Brooklyn yesterday, the police said. The three were found by police officers in a second-floor apartment at 1137 Dean Street, in Prospect Heights. One man, Derrick Vincent, 32, was still alive, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman, but another man and a woman were dead. Mr.
title: 2 Dead and 1 Hurt in Brooklyn Apartment

body: An Early Spring Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; (718) 622-4433. "Love in Bloom," a show of forced bulbs and shrubs including tulips, hyacinths, narcissus, azaleas and Asiatic hybrid lilies, starts Saturday and runs through Feb. 28 in the Steinhardt Conservatory. There will also be an
title: Garden Events: Hearts and Flowers

body: A retired jail supervisor was acquitted yesterday of charges that he murdered Vander L. Beatty, a former State Senator from Brooklyn whose career had collapsed in corruption scandals. A jury in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn found Arthur E. Flournoy, 53, not guilty of charges that he shot Mr. Beatty, a longtime friend, in his Prospect Heights
title: Jury in Brooklyn Acquits Man In Death of Former State Senator
